# Purpose

It may be helpful for understanding of the RMRK 2.0 standard to walk through the RMRKs that are used when running `npx ts-node ./run-mint-sequence.ts`.

# Pre-requisites:
- You'll need to run a Polkadot dev node. Specifically, you'll run ./target/release/polkadot --dev --tmp in a separate terminal window. If you can't do this, check out these instructions. 
- Clone https://github.com/rmrk-team/rmrk2-examples.git, run `yarn` inside projects/scripts folder, and update `.env` inside scripts to include valid [Pinata](https://pinata.cloud) credentials

# Steps
1. Run a Polkadot dev node with  `./target/release/polkadot --dev --tmp`.  Leave that aside and open a new terminal.

2. Run the run-mint-sequence.ts file with `npx ts-node ./run-mint-sequence.ts`.  We'll want to extract all of the block numbers.  They'll vary in your case but will appear like this:
```
Chunky Base created at block:  8
Chunky collection created at block:  12
Chunky NFT minted at block:  16
Chunky base resources added at block:  20
Chunky items collection created at block:  25
CHUNKY ITEMS MINTED AT BLOCK:  28
CHUNKY ITEMS RESOURCE ADDED AND SENT:  31
```

3. This reveals the order of our extrinsics (remarks are just extrinsics, ulimately).  So we did seven things-- (1) Created our base, (2) Created a collection wherein our Chunky NFTs will live, (3) Minted our chunkies, (4) Added our base resources (head, body) to our Chunkies, (5) Created a collection to store our Chunky Items (Bone, Flag, Pencil, Spear), (6) Minted our items, and (7) added our Items to our Chunkies.  Extract the list of block numbers.
```
[8, 12, 16, 20, 25, 28, 31]
```

4. First, let's just visually see one of these blocks, to see the remark that was added.  Open [Polkadot JS Apps](https://polkadot.js.org/apps/?rpc=ws%3A%2F%2F127.0.0.1%3A9944#/explorer) and switch to a local dev node (if the link doesn't automatically take you there).  In the top-right, enter the first of your block numbers and press enter or the play icon to query the hash.

5. Notice under "extrinsics", there is a "system.remark".  This is our remark to create our base collection.  Expand it to notice the remark: Bytes appear as "RMRK::BASE::2.0.0.::...  The remark has more data than will be displayed in the Polkadot JS explorer, but this gives us an idea of how RMRK is interacting with the blockchain.

6. Check the second block in your list.  This is us creating a collection for our Chunkies.  It will similarly appear as "system.remark" but with the header "RMRK::CREATE::2.0.0::..."

7. Check the third block in your list.  This *will* be different.  Here, we are creating all *four* of our Chunkies.  Notice there is no "system.remark"; however, there is a "utility.batchAll".

---
**NOTE**
The difference between the unbatched remark and the batched `batchAll` can be seen in the difference with [api.tx.system.remark(baseEntity.base())](https://github.com/rmrk-team/rmrk2-examples/blob/a72bfea88622554f30fb0bd6d84ebffc5c5bc767/projects/scripts/create-base.ts#L132) being used in `create-base.ts` vs.
[api.tx.utility.batchAll(txs)](https://github.com/rmrk-team/rmrk2-examples/blob/a72bfea88622554f30fb0bd6d84ebffc5c5bc767/projects/scripts/mint-chunky.ts#L198) being used in `mint-chunky.ts`.

---

8. Notice that inside the utility.batchAll, you'll find four remarks (each a "system.remark").  Notice the header for these is "RMRK::MINT::2.0.0:::..."

9. Continue checking through all 7 blocks.  You should find the following:
```
RMRK::BASE::2.0.0::...      // 1.  Unbatched, Creating base objects
RMRK::CREATE::2.0.0::...    // 2.  Unbatched, Creating collection for Chunkies
RMRK::MINT::2.0.0::...      // 3.  Batched, Minting Chunkies
RMRK::RESADD::2.0.0::11-... // 4.  Batched, Adding Base resources to Chunkies
RMRK::CREATE::2.0.0::...    // 5.  Unbatched, Creating collection for Items
RMRK::MINT::2.0.0::...      // 6.  Batched, Creating Items
RMRK::RESADD::2.0.0::24-... // 7a. Batched, Adding Items to Chunkies
RMRK::SEND::2.0.0::24-...   // 7b. Batched, Adding Items to Chunkies
RMRK::EQUIP::2.0.0::24-...  // 7c. Batched, Adding Items to Chunkies
```

10. Let's examine each of these in more detail via code.  Let's create a new file `scripts/deconstruction.ts` with some boilerplate that instantiates the Polkadot API.  Be sure to change `const blocks` to match your correct block arrays.

```typescript
import { getApi } from './utils';
import { WS_URL } from './constants';

const deconstruct = async () => {
    const api = await getApi(WS_URL);
    const blocks = [8, 12, 16, 20, 25, 28, 31];
    for (const block of blocks) {
        console.log("Reading block ", block);
        // All subsequent code will go here.
    }

    process.exit(0);
}

deconstruct();
```

11. Go ahead and run `npx ts-node ./deconstruction.ts` to ensure all is working.  By the way, in the future, go ahead and comment out or delete previous console.log messages to avoid noise.

12. At this point, consider what we want to do.  We want to extract all "RMRK"-headed remarks.  Consider that we want to include remarks whether they are batched or unbatched.  This is a good opportunity to appreciate [rmrk-tools](https://github.com/rmrk-team/rmrk-tools/tree/master/src/rmrk2.0.0/tools) and the [`rmrk-tools-fetch`](https://github.com/rmrk-team/rmrk-tools/blob/master/cli/fetch.ts) operation, which willl make our lives easier in the future.

12. For now, we wont use the tool but rather go through manually.  Let's get our block hash and the block for each of our block IDs.
```typescript
        const bh = await api.rpc.chain.getBlockHash(blockNumber);
        const block = await api.rpc.chain.getBlock(bh);
        console.log("Block ", blockNumber, " has hash ", bh.toString());
```

13. Re-run the file. The output should be similar to:
```
Block  8  has hash  0xeb6a00cfca0cfdea19eb64f40e8a7f68143aa08fb7e3e58eae8047eb949fcab4
Block  12  has hash  0xd0db35bc29049b852af43600ba95a5e729bdf30e4a5be443a2675f8d96756294
Block  16  has hash  0x19d63bea85b93c598eddf0a3bb6bd29fe09f9a89b946173ee84ed5ad93a3352a
Block  20  has hash  0x981d3cebe180f84f23ca6fdb2026f5edec6c2c76c16fa8c16d0888607c377467
Block  25  has hash  0x19c55cdf1b4969fcce3636e540ef13ee51c2cf0f2c2c0aa6044e6fee20f39373
Block  28  has hash  0x0112dcff35607de254ef63e00879352d895877510cf22dedc47bab05a5ce4b9b
Block  31  has hash  0x4e23e7000cac4ab1ad3e1e8b457eb12488ee3914556d5ca0644dc6975113a3c9
```

14. Let's extract the extrinsics and loop through to see their methods.
```
        const extr = block.block.extrinsics;
        for (const ex of extr) {
            console.log("Extrinsic in block ", blockNumber, ": ", ex.method.section);
        }
```

15. Notice the results:
```
Extrinsic in block  8 :  timestamp
Extrinsic in block  8 :  paraInherent
Extrinsic in block  8 :  system
Extrinsic in block  12 :  timestamp
Extrinsic in block  12 :  paraInherent
Extrinsic in block  12 :  system
Extrinsic in block  16 :  timestamp
Extrinsic in block  16 :  paraInherent
Extrinsic in block  16 :  utility
Extrinsic in block  20 :  timestamp
Extrinsic in block  20 :  paraInherent
Extrinsic in block  20 :  utility
Extrinsic in block  25 :  timestamp
Extrinsic in block  25 :  paraInherent
Extrinsic in block  25 :  system
Extrinsic in block  28 :  timestamp
Extrinsic in block  28 :  paraInherent
Extrinsic in block  28 :  utility
Extrinsic in block  31 :  timestamp
Extrinsic in block  31 :  paraInherent
Extrinsic in block  31 :  utility
```

15. We only care about "system" and "utility" (unbatched or batched, respectively), so let's update our loop.
```
        for (const ex of extr) {
            const section = ex.method.section;
            if (section == "utility" || section == "system") {
                console.log("Extrinsic in block ", blockNumber, ": ", ex.method.section);
            }
        }
```

16. Now we have only the seven results we care about.
```
Extrinsic in block  8 :  system
Extrinsic in block  12 :  system
Extrinsic in block  16 :  utility
Extrinsic in block  20 :  utility
Extrinsic in block  25 :  system
Extrinsic in block  28 :  utility
Extrinsic in block  31 :  utility
```

17. However, we will treat system and utility differently, so let's break them apart.  For system, we want to see the remarks directly, which we can do with `.args`:
```typescript
        for (const ex of extr) {
            const section = ex.method.section;
            if (section == "system") {
                console.log("System Extrinsic:", ex.args.toString());
            } else if (section == "utility") {
                // Doing in a few steps
            }
        }
```

18. We can see our three hex-encoded system extrinsics.
```
System Extrinsic: 
System Extrinsic: 
System Extrinsic: 
```

19. Let's take the last as an example, since it is smaller.  We can decode it in the Terminal with `xxd`;
echo  | xxd -r -p

20. We can see our RMRK header in our result:
```
RMRK::CREATE::2.0.0::%7B%22max%22%3A0%2C%22issuer%22%3A%22HNZata7iMYWmk5RvZRTiAsSDhV8366zq2YGb3tLH5Upf74F%22%2C%22symbol%22%3A%22CHNKITMS%22%2C%22id%22%3A%22d43593c715a56da27d-CHNKITMS%22%2C%22metadata%22%3A%22ipfs%3A%2F%2Fipfs%2Fbafkreidaprw5rjxkmnahoqtxnfvlj6zw4sje7ogqqq4itbzjgkp3sqkomq%22%7D
```

21.  However, it's URL-encoded.  We can use a [URL Decoder](https://www.urldecoder.io/) to make it a little more readable:

---

**WARNING** This is an online tool.  Decode at your own risk.

---

```
RMRK::CREATE::2.0.0::{"max":0,"issuer":"HNZata7iMYWmk5RvZRTiAsSDhV8366zq2YGb3tLH5Upf74F","symbol":"CHNKITMS","id":"d43593c715a56da27d-CHNKITMS","metadata":"ipfs://ipfs/bafkreidaprw5rjxkmnahoqtxnfvlj6zw4sje7ogqqq4itbzjgkp3sqkomq"}
```

22. And we can use `jq` to make the JSON portion more readable (be sure to surround your {} in single quotes):
```
echo '{"max":0,"issuer":"HNZata7iMYWmk5RvZRTiAsSDhV8366zq2YGb3tLH5Upf74F","symbol":"CHNKITMS","id":"d43593c715a56da2d-CHNKITMS","metadata":"ipfs://ipfs/bafkreidaprw5rjxkmnahoqtxnfvlj6zw4sje7ogqqq4itbzjgkp3sqkomq"}' | jq
```

23. So for our third extrinsic, here is the whole RMRK, in a pretty, readable format:
```
RMRK::CREATE::2.0.0::
{
  "max": 0,
  "issuer": "HNZata7iMYWmk5RvZRTiAsSDhV8366zq2YGb3tLH5Upf74F",
  "symbol": "CHNKITMS",
  "id": "d43593c715a56da27d-CHNKITMS",
  "metadata": "ipfs://ipfs/bafkreidaprw5rjxkmnahoqtxnfvlj6zw4sje7ogqqq4itbzjgkp3sqkomq"
}
```

24. You can do the same for the first and second system extrinsics, but let's return to the utility extrinsics.
```typescript
        for (const ex of extr) {
            const section = ex.method.section;
            if (section == "system") {
                // console.log("System Extrinsic:", ex.args.toString());
            } else if (section == "utility") {
                const args = ex.method.args[0];
                // @ts-ignore
                args.forEach((el) => {
                    console.log("Utility (Batch) Extrinsic: ", el.args.toString());
                })
            }
        }
```

25. We'll have quite a few results.
```
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  0x524d524b3a3a5345545052494f524954593a3a322e302e303a3a31362d6434333539336337313561353664613237642d43484e4b2d6368756e6b795f342d30303030303030343a3a253542253232306f32524a754e562532322532432532326c6f5a4f396b5768253232253544
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  0x524d524b3a3a53454e443a3a322e302e303a3a32382d6434333539336337313561353664613237642d43484e4b49544d532d6368756e6b795f626f6e652d30303030303030313a3a31362d6434333539336337313561353664613237642d43484e4b2d6368756e6b795f312d3030303030303031
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  0x524d524b3a3a45515549503a3a322e302e303a3a32382d6434333539336337313561353664613237642d43484e4b49544d532d6368756e6b795f626f6e652d30303030303030313a3a626173652d382d43484e4b42532e6368756e6b795f6f626a6563745269676874
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  0x524d524b3a3a53454e443a3a322e302e303a3a32382d6434333539336337313561353664613237642d43484e4b49544d532d6368756e6b795f666c61672d30303030303030323a3a31362d6434333539336337313561353664613237642d43484e4b2d6368756e6b795f322d3030303030303032
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  0x524d524b3a3a45515549503a3a322e302e303a3a32382d6434333539336337313561353664613237642d43484e4b49544d532d6368756e6b795f666c61672d30303030303030323a3a626173652d382d43484e4b42532e6368756e6b795f6f626a6563744c656674
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  0x524d524b3a3a53454e443a3a322e302e303a3a32382d6434333539336337313561353664613237642d43484e4b49544d532d6368756e6b795f70656e63696c2d30303030303030333a3a31362d6434333539336337313561353664613237642d43484e4b2d6368756e6b795f332d3030303030303033
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  0x524d524b3a3a45515549503a3a322e302e303a3a32382d6434333539336337313561353664613237642d43484e4b49544d532d6368756e6b795f70656e63696c2d30303030303030333a3a626173652d382d43484e4b42532e6368756e6b795f6f626a6563745269676874
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  0x524d524b3a3a53454e443a3a322e302e303a3a32382d6434333539336337313561353664613237642d43484e4b49544d532d6368756e6b795f73706561722d30303030303030343a3a31362d6434333539336337313561353664613237642d43484e4b2d6368756e6b795f342d3030303030303034
Utiliity (Batch) Extrinsic:  0x524d524b3a3a45515549503a3a322e302e303a3a32382d6434333539336337313561353664613237642d43484e4b49544d532d6368756e6b795f73706561722d30303030303030343a3a626173652d382d43484e4b42532e6368756e6b795f6f626a6563744c656674
```

26. Running through the same steps as before (we only need `xxd -p -r`--not URL decode then `jq`--because it is a simple EQUIP operation) we can get the results for the last utility/batch extrinsic:
```
echo 0x524d524b3a3a45515549503a3a322e302e303a3a32382d6434333539336337313561353664613237642d43484e4b49544d532d6368756e6b795f73706561722d30303030303030343a3a626173652d382d43484e4b42532e6368756e6b795f6f626a6563744c656674 | xxd -p -r
RMRK::EQUIP::2.0.0::28-d43593c715a56da27d-CHNKITMS-chunky_spear-00000004::base-8-CHNKBS.chunky_objectLeft
```

27. Actually, this is EQUIP, which was not on our original list.  Let's check the last four utility/batch extrinsics, and we'll discover that there are four sets of [RESADD, RESADD, SEND, EQUIP].
```
RMRK::RESADD::2.0.0::28-d43593c715a56da27d-CHNKITMS-chunky_spear-00000004::
{
  "src": "ipfs://ipfs/Qmax4X3v382ZsWY6msE7vcnRw351BKMo5uZ8G8oBBQBDKT/Chunky Items/Chunky_spear_left.svg",
  "thumb": "ipfs://ipfs/Qmax4X3v382ZsWY6msE7vcnRw351BKMo5uZ8G8oBBQBDKT/Chunky Items/Chunky_spear_thumb.png",
  "id": "HoKCMndu",
  "slot": "base-8-CHNKBS.chunky_objectLeft"
}

RMRK::RESADD::2.0.0::28-d43593c715a56da27d-CHNKITMS-chunky_spear-00000004::
{
  "src": "ipfs://ipfs/Qmax4X3v382ZsWY6msE7vcnRw351BKMo5uZ8G8oBBQBDKT/Chunky Items/Chunky_spear_right.svg",
  "thumb": "ipfs://ipfs/Qmax4X3v382ZsWY6msE7vcnRw351BKMo5uZ8G8oBBQBDKT/Chunky Items/Chunky_spear_thumb.png",
  "id": "uYP2mroX",
  "slot": "base-8-CHNKBS.chunky_objectRight"
}

RMRK::SEND::2.0.0::28-d43593c715a56da27d-CHNKITMS-chunky_spear-00000004::
16-d43593c715a56da27d-CHNK-chunky_4-00000004

RMRK::EQUIP::2.0.0::28-d43593c715a56da27d-CHNKITMS-chunky_spear-00000004::
base-8-CHNKBS.chunky_objectLeft
```

28. But why is this?  If we examine `mint-chunk-items.ts`, we learn that there are four sets because we are iterating through four Items:
```
chunkyItems.forEach((item, index) => {
```

29. The container of a single set of [RESADD, RESADD, SEND, EQUIP] is the NFT object `const nft = new NFT({...});`.  It is populated with two RESADDs because each of the Items contains two resources, and those resources are iterated over.
```typescript
      item.resources.forEach((resource) => {
        resaddSendRemarks.push(
          nft.resadd({
              // snip...
        });
      }
```

30. The SEND RMRK comes shortly thereafter.
```typescript
      resaddSendRemarks.push(nft.send(chunkyNft.getId()));
```

31. And the EQUIP RMRK comes immediately after that.
```typescript
      resaddSendRemarks.push(
        nft.equip(
          ...
        )
      );
```

32. In total, here are the nine remark types that we encountered here, with a full JSON-prettified example.

- Creating base object

RMRK::BASE::2.0.0::
```json
{
  "symbol": "CHNKBS",
  "type": "svg",
  "issuer": "HNZata7iMYWmk5RvZRTiAsSDhV8366zq2YGb3tLH5Upf74F",
  "parts": [
    {
      "type": "fixed",
      "id": "chunky_body_1",
      "src": "ipfs://ipfs/Qmax4X3v382ZsWY6msE7vcnRw351BKMo5uZ8G8oBBQBDKT/v1/Chunky_body_v1.svg",
      "z": 0
    },
    {
      "type": "fixed",
      "id": "chunky_body_2",
      "src": "ipfs://ipfs/Qmax4X3v382ZsWY6msE7vcnRw351BKMo5uZ8G8oBBQBDKT/v2/Chunky_body_v2.svg",
      "z": 0
    },
    {
      "type": "fixed",
      "id": "chunky_body_3",
      "src": "ipfs://ipfs/Qmax4X3v382ZsWY6msE7vcnRw351BKMo5uZ8G8oBBQBDKT/v3/Chunky_body_v3.svg",
      "z": 0
    },
    {
      "type": "fixed",
      "id": "chunky_body_4",
      "src": "ipfs://ipfs/Qmax4X3v382ZsWY6msE7vcnRw351BKMo5uZ8G8oBBQBDKT/v4/Chunky_body_v4.svg",
      "z": 0
    },
    {
      "type": "fixed",
      "id": "chunky_head_1",
      "src": "ipfs://ipfs/Qmax4X3v382ZsWY6msE7vcnRw351BKMo5uZ8G8oBBQBDKT/v1/Chunky_head_v1.svg",
      "z": 4
    },
    {
      "type": "fixed",
      "id": "chunky_head_2",
      "src": "ipfs://ipfs/Qmax4X3v382ZsWY6msE7vcnRw351BKMo5uZ8G8oBBQBDKT/v2/Chunky_head_v2.svg",
      "z": 4
    },
    {
      "type": "fixed",
      "id": "chunky_head_3",
      "src": "ipfs://ipfs/Qmax4X3v382ZsWY6msE7vcnRw351BKMo5uZ8G8oBBQBDKT/v3/Chunky_head_v3.svg",
      "z": 4
    },
    {
      "type": "fixed",
      "id": "chunky_head_4",
      "src": "ipfs://ipfs/Qmax4X3v382ZsWY6msE7vcnRw351BKMo5uZ8G8oBBQBDKT/v4/Chunky_head_v4.svg",
      "z": 4
    },
    {
      "type": "fixed",
      "id": "chunky_hand_1",
      "src": "ipfs://ipfs/Qmax4X3v382ZsWY6msE7vcnRw351BKMo5uZ8G8oBBQBDKT/v1/Chunky_hand_v1.svg",
      "z": 3
    },
    {
      "type": "fixed",
      "id": "chunky_hand_2",
      "src": "ipfs://ipfs/Qmax4X3v382ZsWY6msE7vcnRw351BKMo5uZ8G8oBBQBDKT/v2/Chunky_hand_v2.svg",
      "z": 3
    },
    {
      "type": "fixed",
      "id": "chunky_hand_3",
      "src": "ipfs://ipfs/Qmax4X3v382ZsWY6msE7vcnRw351BKMo5uZ8G8oBBQBDKT/v3/Chunky_hand_v3.svg",
      "z": 3
    },
    {
      "type": "fixed",
      "id": "chunky_hand_4",
      "src": "ipfs://ipfs/Qmax4X3v382ZsWY6msE7vcnRw351BKMo5uZ8G8oBBQBDKT/v4/Chunky_hand_v4.svg",
      "z": 3
    },
    {
      "type": "slot",
      "id": "chunky_objectLeft",
      "equippable": [
        "d43593c715a56da27d-CHNKITMS"
      ],
      "z": 1
    },
    {
      "type": "slot",
      "id": "chunky_objectRight",
      "equippable": [
        "d43593c715a56da27d-CHNKITMS"
      ],
      "z": 2
    }
  ]
}
```

-  Creating collection for Chunkies
RMRK::CREATE::2.0.0::
```json
{
  "max": 10000,
  "issuer": "HNZata7iMYWmk5RvZRTiAsSDhV8366zq2YGb3tLH5Upf74F",
  "symbol": "CHNK",
  "id": "d43593c715a56da27d-CHNK",
  "metadata": "ipfs://ipfs/bafkreibzeyetfssguxrzoltvluyjac7hp3bzvzgpa27jkbpek23tqkfpmi"
}
```

- Minting Chunkies
RMRK::MINT::2.0.0::
```json
{
  "collection": "d43593c715a56da27d-CHNK",
  "symbol": "chunky_1",
  "transferable": 1,
  "sn": "00000001",
  "metadata": "ipfs://ipfs/bafkreiefmtvvjnqnlqs2dzavsyble5ft5ly7xtu4pg7tpo5gf4sovputwy"
}
```

- Adding Base resources to Chunkies
RMRK::RESADD::2.0.0::16-d43593c715a56da27d-CHNK-chunky_1-00000001::
```json
{
  "base": "base-8-CHNKBS",
  "id": "FUlowWnG",
  "parts": [
    "chunky_body_1",
    "chunky_head_1",
    "chunky_hand_1",
    "chunky_objectLeft",
    "chunky_objectRight"
  ],
  "thumb": "ipfs://ipfs/Qmax4X3v382ZsWY6msE7vcnRw351BKMo5uZ8G8oBBQBDKT/Chunky%20Preview.png"
}
```

- Creating collection for Items
RMRK::CREATE::2.0.0::
```
{
  "max": 0,
  "issuer": "HNZata7iMYWmk5RvZRTiAsSDhV8366zq2YGb3tLH5Upf74F",
  "symbol": "CHNKITMS",
  "id": "d43593c715a56da27d-CHNKITMS",
  "metadata": "ipfs://ipfs/bafkreidaprw5rjxkmnahoqtxnfvlj6zw4sje7ogqqq4itbzjgkp3sqkomq"
}
```

- Creating Items
RMRK::MINT::2.0.0::
```json
{
  "collection": "d43593c715a56da27d-CHNKITMS",
  "symbol": "chunky_bone",
  "transferable": 1,
  "sn": "00000001",
  "metadata": "ipfs://ipfs/bafkreifbdlldfpfz4vpuv6jmgbtcvbux3djgeps6n4ldhobagdp6ntan54"
}
```

- Adding Items to Resources
RMRK::RESADD::2.0.0::28-d43593c715a56da27d-CHNKITMS-chunky_bone-00000001::
```json
{
  "src": "ipfs://ipfs/Qmax4X3v382ZsWY6msE7vcnRw351BKMo5uZ8G8oBBQBDKT/Chunky Items/Chunky_bone_left.svg",
  "thumb": "ipfs://ipfs/Qmax4X3v382ZsWY6msE7vcnRw351BKMo5uZ8G8oBBQBDKT/Chunky Items/Chunky_bone_thumb.png",
  "id": "O-fxP6t0",
  "slot": "base-8-CHNKBS.chunky_objectLeft"
}
```

- Sending Items to Chunkies
RMRK::SEND::2.0.0::28-d43593c715a56da27d-CHNKITMS-chunky_bone-00000001::
```
16-d43593c715a56da27d-CHNK-chunky_1-00000001
```

- Equipping Items on Chunkies
RMRK::EQUIP::2.0.0::28-d43593c715a56da27d-CHNKITMS-chunky_bone-00000001::
```
base-8-CHNKBS.chunky_objectRight
```

33. That's all.  Challenge: Send a RMRK manually through the Polkadot JS explorer.

RMRK::EQUIP::2.0.0::28-d43593c715a56da27d-CHNKITMS-chunky_bone-00000001::base-8-CHNKBS.chunky_objectLeft
